newsitem.title: USA: Quixote to sell CD unit to Cinram.
newsitem.headline: Quixote to sell CD unit to Cinram.

text.p: Quixote Corp., a diversified technology company, said Monday it has a defininitive agreement to sell its Disc Manufacturing Inc. subsidiary to Cinram Ltd. for about $80 million cash.

DMI, a U.S. manufacturer of compact discs and CD-ROM discs, had sales of $82.4 million in the year ended June 30 and $20.5 million in the first quarter ended Sept. 30, Quixote said. It has manufacturing facilities in Canada, the United States, France and Mexico.
The sale is subject to approval by Quixote shareholders and is expected to be completed in 90 days.
"Our decision to sell DMI was influenced by the increasing competition that has affected the CD industry," said Philip Rollhaus, chairman of Quixote.

"In response to these dynamics, we believe that the industry will be moving toward consolidation and we have decided to recommend to our shareholders that we accept Cinram's offer to purchase DMI," Rollhaus said.
Part of the sale proceeds will be used to reduce Chicago-based Quixote's debt.
Quixote's stock rose $1.25 to $10 early on Nasdaq.
